citeinfo.title: Fresh marsh landcover change maps for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas in 2100 under a 1 meter SLR by 2100 scenario.

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

pubinfo.pubplace: 205 N. Carizzo Street, Corpus Christi, TX, 78401, US

citeinfo.title: Informing conservation and resiliency planning using sea-level rise and storm-surge scenario impact estimates in Corpus Christi Bay

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

descript.abstract: The file was created by determining gains, losses and persistence in fresh marsh landcover categories in 2100 from the 2006 initial landcover map using a 1 meter of SLR by 2100 scenario, which was derived from the SLAMM models of Corpus Christi Bay, Texas.
descript.purpose: This file was created for The Nature Conservancy's Sea Level Rise Project for the northern Gulf of Mexico with funding from the Coastal Bend Bays and Estuary Program (CBBEP). The map represents the gains, lose and persistence of fresh water marshes in 2100 compared to the 2006 intital landcover conditions, which were derived from predicted landcover maps of Corpus Christi Bay, Texas. The landcover maps used for the study area were derived from Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) using the 1m of sea-level rise by 2100 scenario which predict how marshes might migrate inland due to increasing sea levels.

procstep.procdesc: TNC Conservation and Resiliency analyses were created from SLAMM and ADCIRC modeling outputs for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas (see reports at www.SLRportal.org)
